history.content:
Prof. Mathies in Chemistry has a biochemical analysis system-on-a-chip that will be flown to both Europa (moon of Jupiter) and Enceladus (moon of Saturn) to look for signs of life.  With round-trip communication times of an hour or more, these systems will need to be mostly autonomous.  They have lots of microvalves and fluidic chambers and channels that need to be monitored, and they need a dynamic fault-tolerant control system.  We have been asked to help them build the initial sensing and analysis system that will be used in micro gravity ("vomit comet") experiments.  We need students to use cell phone video and audio to measure and debug system state, and ultimately help create the control system.

Experience with audio/video app development and cs188 or equiv. preferred.

Contact Prof. Pister, ksjp@berkeley.edu and/or Nathan Lambert nol@berkeley.edu for more info.
history.subject: ML, vision for space biochemistry
